00003 package Regression;
00004 
00005 $VERSION = 0.1;
00006 
00007 use strict;
00008 
00009 ################################################################
00010 use constant TINY => 1e-8;
00011 use constant DEBUGGING => 0;
00012 ################################################################
00013 =pod
00014 
00015 =head1 NAME
00016 
00017   Regression.pm -       weighted linear regression package (line+plane fitting)
00018 
00019 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00020 
00021 Regression.pm is a multivariate linear regression package.  That is,
00022 it estimates the c coefficients for a line-fit of the type
00023 
00024 y= b(0)*x(0) + b(1)*x1 + b(2)*x2 + ... + b(k)*xk
00025 
00026 given a data set of N observations, each with k independent x variables and
00027 one y variable.  Naturally, N must be greater than k---and preferably
00028 considerably greater.  Any reasonable undergraduate statistics book will
00029 explain what a regression is.  Most of the time, the user will provide a
00030 constant ('1') as x(0) for each observation in order to allow the regression
00031 package to fit an intercept.
00032 
00033 =head1 USAGE
00034 
00035 If the sample data for (x1, x2, y) includes ($x1[$i], $x2[$i], $y[$i]) for 0<=$i<=5, type
00036 
00037 $reg = Regression->new( 3, "y", [ "const", "x1", "x2" ] );
00038 
00039 for($i=0; $i<6; $i++){
00040     $reg->include( $y[$i], [ 1.0, $x1[$i], $x2[$i] ] );
00041 }
00042 
00043 @coeff= $reg->theta();
00044 
00045 $b0 = $coeff[0][0];
00046 $b1 = $coeff[0][1];
00047 $b2 = $coeff[0][2];
00048 
00049 =head1 ALGORITHM
00050 
00051 =head2 Original Algorithm (ALGOL-60):
00052 
00053     W.  M.  Gentleman, University of Waterloo, "Basic Description
00054     For Large, Sparse Or Weighted Linear Least Squares Problems
00055     (Algorithm AS 75)," Applied Statistics (1974) Vol 23; No. 3
00056 
00057 =head2 INTERNALS
00058 
00059 R=Rbar is an upperright triangular matrix, kept in normalized
00060 form with implicit 1's on the diagonal.  D is a diagonal scaling
00061 matrix.  These correspond to "standard Regression usage" as
00062 
00063                 X' X  = R' D R
00064 
00065 A backsubsitution routine (in thetacov) allows to invert the R
00066 matrix (the inverse is upper-right triangular, too!). Call this
00067 matrix H, that is H=R^(-1).
00068 
00069       (X' X)^(-1) = [(R' D^(1/2)') (D^(1/2) R)]^(-1)
00070       = [ R^-1 D^(-1/2) ] [ R^-1 D^(-1/2) ]'
00071 
00072 
00073 
00074 =head2 Remarks
00075 
00076 This algorithm is the statistical "standard." Insertion of a new
00077 observation can be done one obs at any time (WITH A WEIGHT!),
00078 and still only takes a low quadratic time.  The storage space
00079 requirement is of quadratic order (in the indep variables). A
00080 practically infinite number of observations can easily be
00081 processed!
00082 
00083 =head1 AUTHOR
00084 
00085 Naturally, Gentleman invented this algorithm.  Adaptation by ivo
00086 welch. Alan Miller (alan@dmsmelb.mel.dms.CSIRO.AU) pointed out
00087 nicer ways to compute the R^2.
00088 
00089 =head1 Subroutines
00090 
00091 =cut
00092 ################################################################
00093 
00094 
00095 #### let's start with handling of missing data ("nan" or "NaN")
00096 
00097 my $nan= "NaN";
00098 sub isNaN {
00099   if ($_[0] !~ /[0-9nan]/) { die "definitely not a number in NaN: '$_[0]'"; }
00100   return ($_[0]=~ /NaN/i) || ($_[0] != $_[0]);
00101 }
00102 
00103 
00104 ################################################################
00105 
00106 =pod
00107 
00108 =head2 new
00109 
00110 receives the number of variables on each observations (i.e., an integer) and
00111 returns the blessed data structure.  Also takes an optional name for this
00112 regression to remember, as well as a reference to a k*1 array of names for
00113 the X coefficients.
00114 
00115 =cut
00116 
00117 ################################################################
00118 sub new {
00119   my $classname= shift(@_);
00120   my $K= shift(@_); # the number of variables
00121   my $regname= shift(@_) || "with no name";
00122 
00123   if (!defined($K)) { die "Regression->new needs at least one argument for the number of variables"; }
00124   if ($K<=1) { die "Cannot run a regression without at least two variables."; }
00125 
00126   sub zerovec {
00127     my @rv;
00128     for (my $i=0; $i<=$_[0]; ++$i) { $rv[$i]=0; }
00129     return \@rv;
00130   }
00131 
00132   bless {
00133      k => $K,
00134      regname => $regname,
00135      xnames => shift(@_),
00136 
00137      # constantly updated
00138      n => 0,
00139      sse => 0,
00140      syy => 0,
00141      sy => 0,
00142      wghtn => 0,
00143      d => zerovec($K),
00144      thetabar => zerovec($K),
00145      rbarsize => ($K+1)*$K/2+1,
00146      rbar => zerovec(($K+1)*$K/2+1),
00147 
00148      # other constants
00149      neverabort => 0,
00150 
00151      # computed on demand
00152      theta => undef,
00153      sigmasq => undef,
00154      rsq => undef,
00155      adjrsq => undef
00156     }, $classname;
00157 }

00161 =pod
00162 
00163 =head2 dump
00164 
00165 is used for debugging.
00166 
00167 =cut
00168 
00169 ################################################################
00170 sub dump {
00171   my $this= $_[0];
00172   print "****************************************************************\n";
00173   print "Regression '$this->{regname}'\n";
00174   print "****************************************************************\n";
00175   sub print1val {
00176     no strict;
00177     print "$_[1]($_[2])=\t". ((defined($_[0]->{ $_[2] }) ? $_[0]->{ $_[2] } : "intentionally undef"));
00178 
00179     my $ref=$_[0]->{ $_[2] };
00180 
00181     if (ref($ref) eq 'ARRAY') {
00182       my $arrayref= $ref;
00183       print " $#$arrayref+1 elements:\n";
00184       if ($#$arrayref>30) {
00185     print "\t";
00186     for(my $i=0; $i<$#$arrayref+1; ++$i) { print "$i='$arrayref->[$i]';"; }
00187     print "\n";
00188       }
00189       else {
00190     for(my $i=0; $i<$#$arrayref+1; ++$i) { print "\t$i=\t'$arrayref->[$i]'\n"; }
00191       }
00192     }
00193     elsif (ref($ref) eq 'HASH') {
00194       my $hashref= $ref;
00195       print " ".scalar(keys(%$hashref))." elements\n";
00196       while (my ($key, $val) = each(%$hashref)) {
00197     print "\t'$key'=>'$val';\n";
00198       }
00199     }
00200     else {
00201       print " [was scalar]\n"; }
00202   }
00203 
00204   while (my ($key, $val) = each(%$this)) {
00205     $this->print1val($key, $key);
00206   }
00207   print "****************************************************************\n";
00208 }
00209 
00210 ################################################################
00211 =pod
00212 
00213 =head2 print
00214 
00215 prints the estimated coefficients, and R^2 and N.
00216 
00217 =cut
00218 ################################################################
00219 sub print {
00220   my $this= $_[0];
00221   print "****************************************************************\n";
00222   print "Regression '$this->{regname}'\n";
00223   print "****************************************************************\n";
00224 
00225   my $theta= $this->theta();
00226 
00227   for (my $i=0; $i< $this->k(); ++$i) {
00228     print "Theta[$i".(defined($this->{xnames}->[$i]) ? "='$this->{xnames}->[$i]'":"")."]= ".sprintf("%12.4f", $theta->[$i])."\n";
00229   }
00230   print "R^2= ".sprintf("%.3f", $this->rsq()).", N= ".$this->n()."\n";
00231   print "****************************************************************\n";
00232 }
00233 
00234 
00235 ################################################################
00236 =pod
00237 
00238 =head2 include
00239 
00240 receives one new observation.  Call is
00241 
00242   $blessedregr->include( $yvariable, [ $x1, $x2, $x3 ... $xk ], 1.0 );
00243 
00244 where 1.0 is an (optional) weight.  Note that inclusion with a
00245 weight of -1 can be used to delete an observation.
00246 
00247 The function returns the number of observations so far included.
00248 
00249 =cut
00250 ################################################################
00251 sub include {
00252   my $this = shift();
00253   my $yelement= shift();
00254   my $xrow= shift();
00255   my $weight= shift() || 1.0;
00256 
00257   # omit observations with missing observations;
00258   if (!defined($yelement)) { die "Internal Error: yelement is undef"; }
00259   if (isNaN($yelement)) { return $this->{n}; }
00260 
00261   my @xcopy;
00262   for (my $i=1; $i<=$this->{k}; ++$i) {
00263     if (!defined($xrow->[$i-1])) { die "Internal Error: xrow [ $i-1 ] is undef"; }
00264     if (isNaN($xrow->[$i-1])) { return $this->{n}; }
00265     $xcopy[$i]= $xrow->[$i-1];
00266   }
00267 
00268   $this->{syy}+= ($weight*($yelement*$yelement));
00269   $this->{sy}+= ($weight*($yelement));
00270   if ($weight>=0.0) { ++$this->{n}; } else { --$this->{n}; }
00271 
00272   $this->{wghtn}+= $weight;
00273 
00274   for (my $i=1; $i<=$this->{k};++$i) {
00275     if ($weight==0.0) { return $this->{n}; }
00276     if (abs($xcopy[$i])>(TINY)) {
00277       my $xi=$xcopy[$i];
00278 
00279       my $di=$this->{d}->[$i];
00280       my $dprimei=$di+$weight*($xi*$xi);
00281       my $cbar= $di/$dprimei;
00282       my $sbar= $weight*$xi/$dprimei;
00283       $weight*=($cbar);
00284       $this->{d}->[$i]=$dprimei;
00285       my $nextr=int( (($i-1)*( (2.0*$this->{k}-$i))/2.0+1) );
00286       if (!($nextr<=$this->{rbarsize}) ) { die "Internal Error 2"; }
00287       my $xk;
00288       for (my $kc=$i+1;$kc<=$this->{k};++$kc) {
00289     $xk=$xcopy[$kc]; $xcopy[$kc]=$xk-$xi*$this->{rbar}->[$nextr];
00290     $this->{rbar}->[$nextr]= $cbar * $this->{rbar}->[$nextr]+$sbar*$xk;
00291     ++$nextr;
00292       }
00293       $xk=$yelement; $yelement-= $xi*$this->{thetabar}->[$i];
00294       $this->{thetabar}->[$i]= $cbar*$this->{thetabar}->[$i]+$sbar*$xk;
00295     }
00296   }
00297   $this->{sse}+=$weight*($yelement*$yelement);
00298 
00299   # indicate that Theta is garbage now
00300   $this->{theta}= undef;
00301   $this->{sigmasq}= undef; $this->{rsq}= undef; $this->{adjrsq}= undef;
00302 
00303   return $this->{n};
00304 }
00305 
00306 
00307 
00308 ################################################################
00309 
00310 =pod
00311 
00312 =head2 theta
00313 
00314 estimates and returns the vector of coefficients.
00315 
00316 =cut
00317 ################################################################
00318 
00319 sub theta {
00320   my $this= shift();
00321 
00322   if (defined($this->{theta})) { return $this->{theta}; }
00323 
00324   if ($this->{n} < $this->{k}) { return undef; }
00325   for (my $i=($this->{k}); $i>=1; --$i) {
00326     $this->{theta}->[$i]= $this->{thetabar}->[$i];
00327     my $nextr= int (($i-1)*((2.0*$this->{k}-$i))/2.0+1);
00328     if (!($nextr<=$this->{rbarsize})) { die "Internal Error 3"; }
00329     for (my $kc=$i+1;$kc<=$this->{k};++$kc) {
00330       $this->{theta}->[$i]-=($this->{rbar}->[$nextr]*$this->{theta}->[$kc]);
00331       ++$nextr;
00332     }
00333   }
00334 
00335   my $ref= $this->{theta}; shift(@$ref); # we are counting from 0
00336 
00337   # if in a scalar context, otherwise please return the array directly
00338   return $this->{theta};
00339 }
00340 
00341 ################################################################
00342 =pod
00343 
00344 =head2 rsq, adjrsq, sigmasq, ybar, sst, k, n
00345 
00346 These functions provide common auxiliary information.  rsq, adjrsq,
00347 sigmasq, sst, and ybar have not been checked but are likely correct.
00348 The results are stored for later usage, although this is somewhat
00349 unnecessary because the computation is so simple anyway.
00350 
00351 =cut
00352 
00353 ################################################################
00354 
00355 sub rsq {
00356   my $this= shift();
00357   return $this->{rsq}= 1.0- $this->{sse} / $this->sst();
00358 }
00359 
00360 sub adjrsq {
00361   my $this= shift();
00362   return $this->{adjrsq}= 1.0- (1.0- $this->rsq())*($this->{n}-1)/($this->{n} - $this->{k});
00363 }
00364 
00365 sub sigmasq {
00366   my $this= shift();
00367   return $this->{sigmasq}= ($this->{n}<=$this->{k}) ? "Inf" : ($this->{sse}/($this->{n} - $this->{k}));
00368 }
00369 
00370 sub ybar {
00371   my $this= shift();
00372   return $this->{ybar}= $this->{sy}/$this->{wghtn};
00373 }
00374 
00375 sub sst {
00376   my $this= shift();
00377   return $this->{sst}= ($this->{syy} - $this->{wghtn}*($this->ybar())**2);
00378 }
00379 
00380 sub k {
00381   my $this= shift();
00382   return $this->{k};
00383 }
00384 sub n {
00385   my $this= shift();
00386   return $this->{n};
00387 }
00388

00390 ################################################################
00391 =pod
00392 
00393 =head1 DEBUGGING = SAMPLE USAGE CODE
00394 
00395 The sample code included with this package demonstrates regression usage.
00396 To execute it, just set the constant DEBUGGING at the script head to 1, and
00397 do
00398 
00399   perl Regression.pm
00400 
00401 The printout should be
00402 
00403   ****************************************************************
00404   Regression 'sample regression'
00405   ****************************************************************
00406   Theta[0='const']=       0.2950
00407   Theta[1='someX']=       0.6723
00408   Theta[2='someY']=       1.0688
00409   R^2= 0.808, N= 4
00410   ****************************************************************
00411 
00412 =cut
00413 ################################################################
00414 
00415 if (DEBUGGING) {
00416   package main;
00417 
00418   my $reg= Statistics::Regression->new( 3, "sample regression", [ "const", "someX", "someY" ] );
00419   $reg->include( 2.0, [ 1.0, 3.0, -1.0 ] );
00420   $reg->include( 1.0, [ 1.0, 5.0, 2.0 ] );
00421   $reg->include( 20.0, [ 1.0, 31.0, 0.0 ] );
00422   $reg->include( 15.0, [ 1.0, 11.0, 2.0 ] );
00423 
00424 #  $reg->print();   or: my $coefs= $reg->theta(); print @coefs; print $reg->rsq;
00425 # my $coefs= $reg->theta(); print $coeff[0];
00426 }

00428 ################################################################
00429 =pod
00430 
00431 =head1 BUGS/PROBLEMS
00432 
00433 =over 4
00434 
00435 =item Missing
00436 
00437 This package lacks routines to compute the standard errors of
00438 the coefficients.  This requires access to a matrix inversion
00439 package, and I do not have one at my disposal.  If you want to
00440 add one, please let me know.
00441 
00442 =item Perl Problem
00443 
00444 perl is unaware of IEEE number representations.  This makes it a
00445 pain to test whether an observation contains any missing
00446 variables (coded as 'NaN' in Regression.pm).
00447 
00448 =item Others
00449 
00450 I am a novice perl programmer, so this is probably ugly code.  However, it
00451 does seem to work, and I could not find anything equivalent on cpan.
00452 
00453 =back
00454 
00455 =head1 INSTALLATION and DOCUMENTATION
00456 
00457 Installation consists of moving the file 'Regression.pm' into a subdirectory
00458 Statistics of your modules path (e.g., /usr/lib/perl5/site_perl/5.6.0/).
00459

00461 
00462 pod2html -noindex -title "perl weighted least squares regression package" Regression.pm > Regression.html
